name: ssds-single-strand-dna
title: Single-Strand DNA Sequencing
description: Analyze single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) in meiotic recombination hotspots. Map ssDNA formation during meiosis to identify recombination initiation sites, DSB hotspots, and strand-specific processes in mammalian genomes. Samplesheet format: `sample,fastq_1,fastq_2`
content:
SSDS: Single-Strand DNA Sequencing

Single-Strand DNA Sequencing (SSDS) is a specialized technique for mapping single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) regions in the genome, particularly during meiotic recombination. This pipeline analyzes SSDS data to identify recombination hotspots, double-strand break (DSB) sites, and strand-specific DNA processing events.

What is SSDS?

SSDS captures and sequences single-stranded DNA regions that form during meiotic recombination. During meiosis, programmed double-strand breaks (DSBs) are processed to generate extended single-stranded DNA overhangs, which are crucial for homologous recombination and genetic diversity.

The Biology:

  1. DSB Formation: SPO11 creates double-strand breaks at recombination hotspots
  2. 5' to 3' Resection: Exonucleases process DNA ends, generating long 3' ssDNA tails
  3. ssDNA Detection: SSDS specifically captures these single-stranded regions
  4. Strand Specificity: Distinguishes Watson vs Crick strand processing
  5. Hotspot Mapping: Identifies where recombination initiates genome-wide

Why SSDS?

  • Recombination Hotspots: Genome-wide map of meiotic DSB sites
  • Strand Specificity: Distinguish DNA processing on each strand
  • High Resolution: Precise localization of ssDNA regions
  • Mechanistic Insights: Understand recombination initiation and processing
  • Evolutionary Studies: Compare hotspot locations across species
  • PRDM9 Binding: Map zinc-finger protein binding that defines hotspots

SSDS vs Other Methods

FeatureSSDSChIP-seq (DMC1/RAD51)END-seq
TargetssDNA regionsRecombinase-bound DNADSB ends
ResolutionBase-pair~200bp~50bp
Strand Info✅ Yes❌ No✅ Limited
Antibodies❌ No✅ Yes (anti-DMC1)❌ No
RequiresPaired-end readsAny readsSpecial library prep

Important: Paired-End Mode Required

⚠️ SSDS MUST be run in paired-end mode. Single-end sequencing cannot identify the molecular features necessary to distinguish ssDNA from dsDNA. The pipeline specifically looks for:

  • Type 1 reads: Both R1 and R2 map to same strand → dsDNA
  • Type 2 reads: R1 and R2 map to opposite strands → ssDNA

What SSDS Reveals

Recombination Landscape:

  • Hotspot Locations: Genome-wide map of where DSBs occur
  • Hotspot Strength: Quantify recombination frequency per site
  • PRDM9 Motifs: DNA sequences bound by hotspot-defining protein
  • Hotspot Evolution: Species-specific vs conserved sites

DNA Processing Events:

  • 5' to 3' Resection: Track exonuclease activity
  • Strand Bias: Asymmetric processing between strands
  • ssDNA Length: Extent of nuclease processing
  • Temporal Dynamics: Compare early vs late meiotic stages

Pipeline Analysis Steps

  1. Quality Control: FastQC checks read quality and adapter content
  2. Trimming: Trim-galore removes adapters and low-quality bases
  3. Alignment: BWA-MEM maps paired-end reads to reference genome
  4. BAM Processing: Sort and index aligned reads
  5. ssDNA/dsDNA Parsing: Classify reads based on strand orientation
  6. Coverage Tracks: Generate strand-specific BigWig files
  7. Enrichment Calculation: Identify ssDNA-enriched regions (hotspots)
  8. QC Reporting: MultiQC summarizes pipeline metrics

Input Requirements

Samplesheet Format (CSV file with 3 columns):

sample,fastq_1,fastq_2
mouse_testis_ssds,sample_R1.fastq.gz,sample_R2.fastq.gz
mouse_testis_control,control_R1.fastq.gz,control_R2.fastq.gz

Column Descriptions:

  • sample: Unique sample identifier (spaces converted to underscores)
  • fastq_1: Path to R1 FASTQ file (must be .fastq.gz or .fq.gz)
  • fastq_2: Path to R2 FASTQ file (must be .fastq.gz or .fq.gz)

⚠️ Note: If you have multiple sequencing runs for the same sample, pool them beforehand.

Reference Genome Selection

Choose the appropriate genome for your organism:

  • 🐭 Mouse: mm10 (GRCm38) or mm39 (GRCm39) - Most common for SSDS studies
  • 🧑 Human: hg38 (GRCh38) or hg19 (GRCh37)
  • 🐀 Rat: rn6 or rn7
  • 🔬 Other organisms: Ensure genome is available in iGenomes or provide custom FASTA

Key Outputs

  • ssDNA/dsDNA BAM files: Classified reads for downstream analysis
  • BigWig coverage tracks: Strand-specific signal for genome browsers
  • Hotspot regions: Enriched ssDNA sites (recombination hotspots)
  • QC metrics: Alignment rates, duplication levels, library complexity
  • MultiQC report: Comprehensive quality control summary

Scientific Applications

  • Meiosis Research: Map recombination initiation sites
  • Fertility Studies: Understand reproductive biology
  • Evolutionary Biology: Compare hotspot evolution across species
  • PRDM9 Studies: Investigate hotspot determination mechanisms
  • Chromosome Biology: Study chromosome pairing and synapsis
  • Disease Research: Aberrant recombination in infertility

QC Metrics to Monitor

  • Alignment Rate: Should be >85% for good quality data
  • Duplicate Rate: <30% indicates good library complexity
  • Type 1 vs Type 2 ratio: Depends on enrichment efficiency
  • Hotspot Enrichment: ssDNA signal at known recombination sites

Pipeline Technical Details

  • 🔧 Aligner: BWA-MEM (optimized for paired-end reads)
  • 📊 Coverage: Strand-specific BigWig tracks
  • 🎯 Read Classification: Custom scripts parse ssDNA vs dsDNA
  • ✅ Quality Filters: Proper pairing, MAPQ thresholds, duplicate removal
  • 📈 Enrichment: Statistical analysis of ssDNA-enriched regions

Important Notes

⚠️ Pipeline Status: This pipeline was archived on March 10, 2023, and is no longer actively maintained by nf-core. It remains functional but may not receive updates. Use the dev branch for the most recent version.

📖 Citation: If you use this pipeline, please cite the original SSDS method paper:
Khil et al. (2012) "Sensitive mapping of recombination hotspots using sequencing-based detection of ssDNA" Genome Res.

Perfect for Research in: Meiosis • Recombination • Fertility • Evolutionary genetics • Chromosome biology • PRDM9 studies • Reproductive health
